Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story:
I sit at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, the script for our new service open in front of me. The phone rings, and I launch into my pitch, but the prospect interrupts with a barrage of technical questions. My script only covers the basics, and I fumble for answers, feeling the pressure to keep the call going and handle every objection. My supervisor expects me to be confident, persuasive, and never admit uncertainty. Each call leaves me more drained, my mind racing with doubts about whether I’m really helping anyone.

As I glance at the clock, I remember it’s almost time for Sunday worship. I haven’t been to church in weeks, always telling myself I’ll go when work slows down. My church expects me to be present, to worship, to support the community. I miss the peace I feel there, the sense of belonging. But if I leave now, I’ll miss my sales targets, and my manager will notice. My heart aches as I weigh the demands—should I stay and keep calling, or step away and seek the comfort of my faith?
